skills.name: Identify equivalent fractions when presented as numbers
Use inequality notation to order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number
Use inequality notation to order fractions whose denominators are not multiples of the same number
Represent positive non-unit fractions on a number line

explanations.A: Each of these circles is split into 3 equal parts, so each part is 1/3. Picture shading 12 of these parts, is that the same as 12 whole ones?
explanations.B: Each of these circles is split into 3 equal parts, so each part is 1/3. Picture shading 12 of these parts, would that make 3 whole ones?
explanations.C: Each of these circles is split into 3 equal parts, so each part is 1/3. If we shade all 12 parts, that would be 4 whole ones. We can also say that 3/3 = 1, and 12/3 = 4 x 3/3 so it is equivalent to 4.
explanations.D: Each of these circles is split into 3 equal parts, so each part is 1/3. Picture shading 12 of these parts, how many whole ones is that?

explanations.A: Each of these squares is split into 4 equal parts, so each part is 1/4. If we shade all 12 parts, that would be 3 whole ones. We can also say that 4/4 = 1, and 12/4 = 3 x 4/4 so it is equivalent to 3.
explanations.B: Each of these squares is split into 4 equal parts, so each part is 1/4. Picture shading 12 of these parts, is that the same as 16 whole ones?
explanations.C: Each of these squares is split into 4 equal parts, so each part is 1/4. Picture shading 12 of these parts, would that make 4 whole ones?
explanations.D: Each of these squares is split into 4 equal parts, so each part is 1/4. Picture shading 12 of these parts, how many whole ones is that?

explanations.A: You might be thinking of 2/4... It takes two jumps on the scale to get from 0 to 1, so each jump is 1/2. Can you count 4 jumps along from 0 to reach 4/2?
explanations.B: Not quite... It takes two jumps on the scale to get from 0 to 1, so each jump is 1/2. Can you count 4 jumps along from 0 to reach 4/2?
explanations.C: Almost, but I think you have counted the start of the scale as 1/2. The start of the scale is 0, so the next mark on the scale will be 1/2, then 2/2...
explanations.D: It takes two jumps on the scale to get from 0 to 1, so each jump is 1/2. 4 jumps along from 0 take us to D. We can also say 4 halves is equal to 2 whole ones, so 4/2 is at 2 on the scale.

explanations.A: You might be thinking of 2/6... It takes two jumps on the scale to get from 0 to 1, so each jump is 1/2. Can you count 6 jumps along from 0 to reach 6/2?
explanations.B: It takes two jumps on the scale to get from 0 to 1, so each jump is 1/2. Can you count 6 jumps along from 0 to reach 6/2?
explanations.C: It takes two jumps on the scale to get from 0 to 1, so each jump is 1/2. 6 jumps along from 0 take us to C. We can also say 6 halves is equal to 3 whole ones, so 6/2 is at 3 on the scale.
explanations.D: I think maybe you've found the difference between the 6 and 4. It takes two jumps on the scale to get from 0 to 1, so each jump is 1/2. Can you count 6 jumps along from 0 to reach 6/2?

explanations.A: 7/7 makes one whole one, so would 21/7 make 7 whole ones?
explanations.B: It looks like you subtracted 7 from 21, but the line in a fraction doesn't mean subtract, it means divide.
explanations.C: 7/7 makes one whole one, so would 21/7 make 21 whole ones?
explanations.D: 7/7 makes one whole one. 21/7 = 3 x 7/7, so it is equivalent to 3 whole ones.

explanations.A: 7/7 makes one whole one, so would 42/7 make 7 whole ones?
explanations.B: 7/7 makes one whole one, so would 42/7 make 42 whole ones?
explanations.C: It looks like you subtracted 7 from 42, but the line in a fraction doesn't mean subtract, it means divide.
explanations.D: 7/7 makes one whole one. 42/7 = 6 x 7/7, so it is equivalent to 6 whole ones.

explanations.A: 10/10 makes one whole one. 20/10 = 2 x 10/10 so it is equivalent to 2 whole ones. 2 is less than 3 so we use the less than symbol <
explanations.B: 20 looks bigger than 3 but we need to convert 20/10 into whole ones to compare with 3. If 10/10 makes one whole one, how many whole ones is 20/10 equivalent to?
explanations.C: If 10/10 makes one whole one, how many whole ones is 20/10 equivalent to? Is this less or more than 3?
explanations.D: It's hard to compare these numbers as they are, but we can write 20/10 as a whole number. If 10/10 makes one whole one, how many whole ones is 20/10 equivalent to?

explanations.A: If 5/5 makes one whole one, how many whole ones is 30/5 equivalent to? Is this less or more than 5?
explanations.B: 5/5 makes one whole one. 30/5 = 6 x 5/5 so it is equivalent to 6 whole ones. 6 is greater than 5 so we use the more than symbol >
explanations.C: If 5/5 makes one whole one, how many whole ones is 30/5 equivalent to? Is this less or more than 5?
explanations.D: It's hard to compare these numbers as they are, but we can write 30/5 as a whole number. If 5/5 makes one whole one, how many whole ones is 30/5 equivalent to?

explanations.A: 7/7 makes one whole one, so 28/7 makes 4 whole ones. 3/3 makes one whole one, so 18/3 makes 6 whole ones. 4 is less than 6, so we use the less than symbol <
explanations.B: We need to convert these to whole numbers before we can compare them. 7/7 makes one whole one, so how many whole ones is 28/7 equivalent to? 3/3 makes one whole one, so how many whole ones is 18/3 equivalent to? Which is greater?
explanations.C: We need to convert these to whole numbers before we can compare them. 7/7 makes one whole one, so how many whole ones is 28/7 equivalent to? 3/3 makes one whole one, so how many whole ones is 18/3 equivalent to? Which is greater?
explanations.D: It's hard to compare these numbers as they are, but we can write them both as whole numbers. 7/7 makes one whole one, so how many whole ones is 28/7 equivalent to? 3/3 makes one whole one, so how many whole ones is 18/3 equivalent to? Which is greater?

explanations.A: We need to convert these to whole numbers before we can compare them. 2/2 makes one whole one, so how many whole ones is 18/2 equivalent to? 6/6 makes one whole one, so how many whole ones is 24/6 equivalent to? Which is greater?
explanations.B: 2/2 makes one whole one, so 18/2 makes 9 whole ones. 6/6 makes one whole one, so 24/6 makes 4 whole ones. 9 is greater than 4, so we use the greater than symbol >
explanations.C: We need to convert these to whole numbers before we can compare them. 2/2 makes one whole one, so how many whole ones is 18/2 equivalent to? 6/6 makes one whole one, so how many whole ones is 24/6 equivalent to? Which is greater?
explanations.D: It's hard to compare these numbers as they are, but we can write them both as whole numbers. 2/2 makes one whole one, so how many whole ones is 18/2 equivalent to? 6/6 makes one whole one, so how many whole ones is 24/6 equivalent to? Which is greater?
